content: Dear Military Members: How do you do? My name is Rachael, and I am getting ready to begin studying for my ASVAB exam as soon as my quarter is over. I know that Military.com offers a few ASVAB Practice Tests, but I would like to purchase an ASVAB prep book. Does anyone have any good recommendation(s) on which is the "best" ASVAB prep. book out in the market? Thank you, Rachael T.
reply: Dear Military Members: How do you do? My name is Rachael, and I am getting ready to begin studying for my ASVAB exam as soon as my quarter is over. I know that Military.com offers a few ASVAB Practice Tests, but I would like to purchase an ASVAB prep book. Does anyone have any good recommendation(s) on which is the "best" ASVAB prep. book out in the market? Thank you, Rachael T.

content: Rachael, I am going to assume you are likely in high school or recently graduated. I don't know about California, but in Alabama, about two to four weeks prior to the ASVAB, our high schools have a signup form, and give you a prep. book when you sign up for the test. The one I got looked like it was on 6th grade level math and basic logic. Turns out, it was harder than the test itself. I'll be brutally honost, if you maintained a C average or better, and can recognize patterns, you should have no problems at all with the ASVAB. Also, when I finished my training, I went and did a week of RAP duty(Recruiter Assistance Program), and at the recruiting station we had a practice ASVAB on the computer, and we had every potential recruit take it. All but one of some 50 potential recruits did better on the actual test than the practice test. "http://www.testprepreview.com/asvab_practice.htm" has a number of "self assessments" that covers everything you can imagine, and it looks to be pretty comprehensive, so you may want to give it a try. Also the military.com test is a very good representation of the real thing, I highly recommend it. {edit} I see I type too slowly... “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: Thank you everyone for being so kind and helpful. Pardon my late response. I've been very busy with school. I actually purchased the McGraw Hill ASVAB. I am currently reviewing the Math Section, and then I'll review General Science, English, and the miscellaneous. I have a list of MOS that I am interested in, and I am studying those that are the most important. Mainly, the subjects that comprise the AFQT score and General Science. Thank you everyone, and Happy Monday Rachael

content: Hello AceShaw how are you? When will you be taking the ASVAB? I started studying for my ASVAB last week, and so far so good. The Math isn't terribly challenging, and my goal is to ace the entire ASVAB. Except, I do not think I'll do particularly well under the mechanics section. Which MOS are you interested in? My first choice is Intelligence, and I have read that it is necessary to choose two back-up MOS just in case the first choice isn't available. Have a wonderful week, Rachael
reply: Hello AceShaw how are you? When will you be taking the ASVAB? I started studying for my ASVAB last week, and so far so good. content: Rachael, at the risk of being bombarded with posters in agreement....I am no Albert Einstein. Standing by for incoming. I can't remember if it was an ASVAB or whatever I took back in 1981 for the US Coast Guard. In high school I was an average student. I had a hard time keeping interested in things that bored me, ie: Algebra, etc. Anyway, my point is that I studied whatever the material was they gave me, took the test and passed with a high score. Study but don't get too freaked out about it and I'm betting you'll do fine. Don

content: Heck... I didn't know you could even study for that test back in the 70s Good luck on the ASVAB... the higher you score the more opportunities you will have. Pay specific attention to the areas on GT and ST. (if those two still exist)

content: Hello Don and ArtMarsh: Thank you for both your replies. As a matter of fact, thank you everyone for your kind support! I appreciate it very much, and I am certain it will need it very much as the time gets closer and closer. The ASVAB consists of: 1. General Science (GS) 2. Arithmetic Reasoning (AR) 3. Word Knowledge (WK) 4. Paragraph Comprehension (PC) 5. Numerical Operations (NO) 6. Coding Speed (CS) 7. Auto and Shop Information (AS) 8. Mathematics Knowledge (MK) 9. Mechanical Comprehension (MC) 10. Electronics Information (EI) 11. Sum of Word Knowledge and Paragraph Comprehension (VE) I've attempted the ASVAB Tests here on Military.com. I scored fairly well on Math and English, but I most definitely need to brush up on my General Science. It has been a very long time since I was in a science class. I graduated high school in 2002, and being in college my major does not require any science courses. Have a nice day everyone! My econometrics course is starting in 10mins. Take care and Thank you, Thank you, Rachael T.
reply: Hello Don and ArtMarsh: Thank you for both your replies. As a matter of fact, thank you everyone for your kind support! Take care and Thank you, Thank you, Rachael T. Interesting... I wnder how well I would do on the ASVAB today... This is what it was... in days of yor (old) {or something close to that} CL — Clerical CO — Combat Operations EL — Electronics FA — Field Artillery GM — General Maintenance GT — General Technical MM — Mechanical Maintenance OF — Operators and Food SC — Surveillance and Communications ST — Skilled Technical So I am not going to get stupid and try to tell you which will be the most important areas to score well in. In my day the GT was the most important followed closely by the ST if you wanted something other than Infantry, clerical, or cook (plus a few other CMFs)
